Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: ZnO Nanowires as Building Blocks for High Performance Transparent Electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this GOALI proposal is the fabrication of high mobility, ZnO nanowire field-effect transistor, with both n-type and p-type doing, on polymer or glass substrate for transparent and flexible electronics applications. The approach is to: 1) Synthesize single crystal n- and p-type ZnO nanowires during high temperature deposition on a growth substrate, 2) Perform systematic analysis of the defects in ZnO nanowires, and understand the dopant compensation mechanisms, 3) Characterize and simulate transport properties of parallel aligned nanowire arrays through field effect transistor, and 4) Explore mass integration of parallel-aligned ZnO nanowire arrays onto transparent glass or plastic substrates at low temperatures.

The intellectual merit lies in the transformative concepts and approaches that will greatly increase the performance, especially device speed, of transparent electronics. Through a collaborative effort between Arizona State University and Structured Materials Industries, Inc., integration of robust and reliable ZnO NW devices onto polymer substrates will be pursued, beginning with designed synthesis process to understanding their solid state chemistry, and then scaling up for subsequent device integration.

The broader impact of the proposed activity is the low temperature integration of high mobility materials (synthesized at high temperatures) onto transparent substrates. The educational aspect will have far reaching consequences; for example, the program will train personnel (including student from a rich pool of underrepresented minorities in Arizona) in a technologically important and futuristic area, so that they can apply their science and engineering skills in the US industries and research laboratories upon completion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, the focus of much research effort has been in the field of flexible and transparent electronics for their potential to completely revolutionize consumer products.  Unlike the trend of conventional microelectronics, which focuses on scaling and performance, flexible electronics capitalize on the possibility to create unique integrated functionality and form factors including implantable, conformable, and even transparent designs.  During this award period, we developed wide bandgap UV detectors, especially those based on Zinc Oxide (ZnO), an “all-visible” transparent UV detector on flexible polymer substrate that would enable novel capabilities including attachment capability to windows, or atop other devices which require full exposure to visible light. One of the key goals of this NSF project is to develop and explore ZnO growth and device fabrication process initially at university on small-scale substrate and subsequently transfer knowledge gained at ASU to larger industrial environment.  Industrial Partner Structured Materials Industries, Inc. (SMI) working with ASU, has been able to demonstrate controlled growth of ZnO NWs at low temperatures using the less expensive and more scalable vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) growth process, using the sublimination of Zn as the source material for ZnO growth.  This work describes the methodology of a low-cost fabrication technique for producing periodic sub-micron structures over a large area, using a polymer mask. Furthermore, under this award, a new technique of fabricating tunable optical grating has been developed. A thin film of gold/palladium or silica is deposited on a stretched polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrate. Release of the tension forms a buckling sinusoidal pattern on the surface. The PDMS substrates are then used as masks in soft contact optical lithography, bypassing the need for an expensive lithographic process toward creating regular patterns on a traditional masks. Pattern transfers are conducted using an ultraviolet lamp and the fabrication of more complex periodic structures through multiple exposures is explored. Such technique provides a new way of fabricating flexible and transparent electronics and optoelectronics. The PIs of this project have dedicated significant effort on training both graduate and undergraduate students and prepare their scientific research ability as well as interpersonal skills required for future careers
